qas.question: What is the name given to the input string of a computational problem?
In computational complexity theory, what is the term given to describe the baseline abstract question needing to be solved?
Is a problem instance typically characterized as abstract or concrete?
What is another name for any given measure of input associated with a problem?
What is the general term used to describe the output to any given input in a problem instance?
What can be viewed as a limited collection of instances together with a solution for every instance?
What is the name given to the input string of a computational solution?
What term refers to the concrete question to be solved?
What is the output corresponding to the given question?
What is a particular measure input associated with the a theory?

context: A <b5_0>computational problem<b5_0/> can be viewed as an infinite collection of <a3_0>instances<a3_0/> together with a <a4_0>solution<a4_0/> for every instance. The input string for a computational problem is referred to as <a0_1>a <a0_0><a0_2><b6_0>problem instance<b6_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, and should not be confused with <a1_0><b7_0>the problem<b7_0/><a1_0/> itself. In computational complexity theory, <a1_1>a <a1_2>problem<a1_2/><a1_1/> refers to the <a2_2>abstract<a2_2/> question to be solved. In contrast, an instance of this problem is a rather <a2_0><a2_1>concrete<a2_1/><a2_0/> utterance, which can serve as the input for a decision problem. For example, consider the problem of primality testing. The instance is a number (e.g. 15) and the solution is "yes" if the number is prime and "no" otherwise (in this case "no"). Stated another way, <a3_1><b9_0>the <a3_2>instance<b9_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/> is a particular input to the problem, and <a4_1><b8_0>the <a4_2>solution<b8_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/> is the output corresponding to the given input.
